questions.text: You are called to see a 12-hour-old male infant who was born to a 19-year-old G1 woman with no prenatal care. She presented to the emergency room completely dilated and crowning. The baby was born minutes later. On examination at 12 hours, the baby is febrile and tachypneic. A chest X ray confirms the presence of pneumonia. What is the most likely infectious agent?
questions.solution:
• GBS is the most common cause of infection in the newborn infant, followed by E. coli (option b) and L. monocytogenes. GBS is the most common cause of pneumonia, septicemia, UTI, and meningitis.
  • The risk of early-onset (within the first 7 days of life) GBS infection can be reduced with the antenatal administration of appropriate antimicrobials. The use of perinatal antimicrobials has no effect on the occurrence of late-onset (after 7 days of life) GBS disease.
  • RSV and Pneumococcal infections are common after infancy and very rare in neonates. (option c, d)

questions.text:
Choose the correct statement regarding physiological jaundice in neonates
A. It is caused by inadequate hepatic conjugation capacity
B. It is caused by increased lysis of RBCs
C. Threshold for starting phototherapy is higher in pre-term babies
D. Caput succedaneum is a risk factor
questions.solution:
• The exaggerated physiological jaundice in neonates is a result of increased RBC lysis along with low hepatic capacity to conjugate the increased bilirubin load.
  • In pre term babies the threshold for starting the phototherapy and exchange transfusion is lower due to increased risk of neuronal damage at low bilirubin levels. (statement c)
  • Cephalhematoma is a known risk factor for jaundice due to lysis of RBC accumulated in the lesion. (statement d)

questions.text: A newborn baby comes to you at 7th day of life with refusal to feeding. Baby also had fever since 2 days and reduced activity since a day before. On examination child remains sleepy, wakes up only for feeding. Sucking is poor. Mother is confident that child was sucking very well for first 5 days. You suspect neonatal sepsis in the baby. Which of the following investigation is not a part of neonatal septic screen?
questions.solution:
The primary investigation in a suspected neonatal sepsis screen includes

  • Blood culture (option a)
  • Urine culture (option a)
  • CSF culture
  • Tracheal aspirate culture (in intubated babies)
  • Absolute neutrophil count and immature to total neutrophil ratio
  • Platelet count
  • CSF cell count with protein and glucose levels
  • C Reactive Protein (option c)
  • Procalcitonin (option b)

questions.text:
Select the correct statement/s for congenital toxoplasmosis infection
A. They are asymptomatic at birth
B. Periventricular calcification in CT scan is a characteristic
C. Chorioretinitis is a classical feature
D. IgG levels are diagnostic
questions.solution:
• Most newborns with congenital toxoplasmosis are asymptomatic at birth (statement a). Symptoms presenting in newborns with toxoplasmosis can include temperature instability, rash (maculopapular or petechial), hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, generalized lymphadenopathy, pneumonitis, microcephaly, meningoencephalitis, seizures, and chorioretinitis.
  • The classic triad of chorioretinitis, (statement c) hydrocephalus, and diffuse intracranial calcifications is rarely seen in congenital toxoplasmosis. (statement b)
  • IgM and IgA levels for toxoplasma Gondii are diagnostic (statement d). PCR from placenta or amniotic fluid helps in definitive diagnosis.
  • Pyrimethamine and sulfadiazine in combination with folinic acid is recommended as first-line therapy for toxoplasmosis.

questions.text: A mother with no prenatal care gives birth to a term infant with findings of IUGR, microcephaly and hepatosplenomegaly. His hemogram shows thrombocytopenia. BERA test reveals sensorineural hearing loss. Ophthalmic examination shows chorioretinitis. The most important diagnostic study for evaluation in this newborn is
questions.solution:
• The newborn in the question shows characteristics of congenital CMV infection.
  • In addition to those findings mentioned above, these patients can have petechiae and purpura, ventriculomegaly, periventricular calcifications, cerebral atrophy, cortical dysplasia, and chorioretinitis.
  • The most important diagnostic study in the evaluation of newborn CMV disease is viral culture, preferably done before 3 weeks of life to help exclude the possibility of perinatal CMV acquisition.
  • Viral PCR is a useful adjunct to culture techniques but does not replace viral culture.
  • Tissue biopsy, while sometimes used for diagnosis, is not standard and is more commonly used in the lung and liver than in the brain.
  • CMV antibody titers are generally not helpful in diagnosis.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:
Causes of permanent congenital hypothyroidism are:

  • Thyroid dysgenesis (most common)
  • Thyroid agenesis
  • TSH resistance
  • Thyroid dyshormonogenesis (2nd most common)
  • Central hypothyroidism

choices.text: This infant needs an audiology evaluation because sensorineural hearing loss is a common association
This infant needs a renal ultrasound because she is likely to have renal abnormalities
The infant's condition is likely to have occurred because of a maternal illness during the third trimester
Intravenous antiviral therapy should be initiated and viral cultures should be obtained

questions.text: A full-term baby girl is born small for gestational age. She has absence of bilateral red reflexes in eyes cataracts, multiple petechial spots on skin, and a continuous machine-like murmur on auscultation. Which of the following statements about the diagnosis of the baby is accurate?
questions.solution:
• This infant has the classic features of congenital rubella syndrome including low birth weight, heart defect (patent ductus arteriosus), and congenital cataracts.
  • Other clinical findings associated with congenital rubella syndrome include purpura, hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, retinopathy, glaucoma, pulmonary artery stenosis, meningoencephalitis, thrombocytopenia, and hemolytic anemia.
  • Long-term sequelae of congenital rubella include
    • Sensorineural hearing loss
    • Neurodevelopmental abnormalities
    • Growth retardation
    • Endocrine disease (diabetes mellitus, thyroid dysfunction)
  • Maternal infection may or may not be clinically apparent, and infection during the first month of pregnancy is most likely to result in fetal infection with the involvement of multiple organs.
  • No treatment is available for CRS. All the management is supportive.

IMPORTANT POINTS:

  • Nerve deafness is most common finding of CRS
  • Salt and Pepper retinopathy is characteristic ophthalmic finding
  • Classical triad include, Cataract, Deafness and PDA (congenital heart disease)

choices.text: Hospitalize, send vesicle fluid and CSF culture, start acyclovir
Order an EEG and brain MRI immediately
Perform a Tzanck smear and send the patient home if it is negative
Prescribe an antifungal cream and zinc oxide

questions.text: A 12-day newborn baby is brought to you by parents with painful perianal rashes as follows. What should be the line of management for the baby?
questions.solution:
• The child has painful vesicular rashes as shown, which is likely to be herpes infection.
  • Infants with skin, eye, and mouth disease generally present at 5-11 days of life and typically demonstrate these small vesicles,
  • In contrast to children and adults, neonates with suspected herpes skin lesions require parenteral antiviral therapy to prevent more serious sequelae as well as CSF analysis to define the extent of disease. HSV PCR of the CSF is the standard for diagnosis.
  • Tzanck smears have low sensitivity and EEG ma have nonspecific findings (option b, c). The absence of fever does not indicate that the rash is from a benign etiology.

questions.text: A full term baby born to a mother with hypothyroidism, needs to be screened for congenital hypothyroidism ideally at what age?
questions.solution:
• A newborn screening for congenital hypothyroidism must be done at 3-4 days of life coupled with newborn screening for inborn errors of metabolism.
  • Screening test that are positive must be reassessed with a repeat venous sample and read according to cut-off values for the age.

questions.text:
Which of the following complication is not expected in babies of diabetic mother?
A. Hypoglycemia
B. Intrauterine growth retardation
C. Hypocalcemia
D. Ventricular septal defect
E. Neural tube defect
questions.solution:
Common presentations in an infant of diabetic mother are

  • Hypoglycemia (selection A)
  • Hypocalcemia (Selection C)
  • Neural tube defects
  • Macrosomia

Other manifestations

  • Respiratory distress syndrome
  • Cardiomegaly
  • Cardiac malformations (VSD, TGA, Truncus arteriosus, Double outlet right ventricle, tricuspid atresia, COA) (Selection D)
  • Lumbosacral agenesis
  • Neural tube defect (Selection E)
  • Renal agenesis, hydronephrosis
  • Anorectal atresia
  • Small left colon syndrome

questions.text: While giving phototherapy to a neonate for neonatal jaundice, the effectiveness of phototherapy depends on all except
questions.solution:
• The therapeutic effect of phototherapy depends on
    • Light energy emitted in the effective range of wavelengths,
    • Distance between the lights and the infant,
    • Surface area of exposed skin
    • Rate of hemolysis and in vivo metabolism and excretion of bilirubin.
  • Dark skin does not reduce the efficacy of phototherapy.

questions.text: A 34-week-gestation neonate is admitted to the NICU with respiratory distress. The mother's pregnancy was complicated by mild gestational hypertension. A primary cesarean delivery was performed after failed induction of labor. Meconium was noted in the amniotic fluid. The Apgar score was 8 at 1 and 5 minutes. The neonate is placed on continuous positive airway pressure. Baby is on CPAP respiratory support. Early onset sepsis is suspected. Mother has fever. Of the following, the factor in this neonate's history MOST closely associated with this diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• Early-onset sepsis (EOS) continues to be a significant source of neonatal morbidity and mortality.
  • Risk factor for Early onset sepsis are:
    • Prematurity- <37 weeks
    • Maternal fever/sepsis
    • Prolonged rupture of membrane
    • Prelabor rupture of membrane

questions.text: A newborn infant is found at birth to have proximal hypospadias in a short phallus with bilateral nonpalpable gonads. The karyotype is suggestive of XX and the 17-hydroxyprogesterone is elevated. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Child is genotypic female. Phenotypically child has ambiguous genitals as the phallus is small and gonads are non-palpable. No other signs of shock or distress is mentioned. 17-OHP is elevated. These are suggestive of CAH with 21 hydroxylase deficiency.
  • Mixed gonadal dysgenesisis characterized by a unilateral streak gonad with a contralateral, often dysgenetic, testis (option b). A variant where two dysgenetic testes are present, rather than one dysgenetic testis and a streak gonad, is called partial gonadal dysgenesis. Most of patients have a 45,XO/46,XY karyotype and persistence of Müllerian structures associated with varying degrees of masculinization, including normal male genitalia.
  • Klinefelter syndrome has XXY and Turner has XO karyotype. (option c, d)

questions.text: A full-term baby with weight 3.5kg born to a primi mother with minimal antenatal care develops respiratory distress within 1 hour of birth. Child cried immediately after birth. On examination the baby looks an appropriate size for his gestational age, he is not dysmorphic. His lips and tongue appear slightly blue. He is making an intermittent grunting expiratory sound, and his respiratory rate is 70 breaths/min. Air entry is reduced on the left side of his chest, with no increase in resonance on percussion. CVS examination WNL(with in normal limit). His abdomen appears slightly concave. His chest radiograph is shown. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The child in the question has all the findings suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia.
  • The X ray is suggestive of air filled loops in chest, i.e., intestinal loops. There is mediastinal shift to the right. As bowels loops are shifted in chest, abdomen is scaphoid. Due to compression of the intestines in the lung, lungs are immature and hence develops respiratory distress.
  • Immediate surgical exploration and reduction of loops into the abdomen is the definitive management.
  • The child had developed distress immediately after birth, with no history of illness in mother, so sepsis or pneumonia is less likely. (option c)
  • Transient tachypnea of newborn is the most common cause of respiratory distress in full term babies. But, the X ray findings and clinical findings are not matching. (option a)
  • There are no risk factors for pneumothorax, as child had cried spontaneously. (option b) Also, scaphoid abdomen is not seen in pneumothorax. X ray does not show any signs of pneumothorax.
